Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Jeffrey S. Moore of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign will develop new force-sensitive molecules (mechanophores) that, under mechanical stress, undergo a series of chemical reactions to produce acid. The research has three complementary components. In the first part, the research will focus on the design and study of cascade reactions, where a mechanochemical reaction leads to a high energy intermediate, which will undergo one or several reactions, eventually producing acid. In the second part, the acid production will be validated by developing analytical methods to study the acid production and the physical and chemical changes in the polymer structure concurrently. Finally, by combining selective mechanochemical acid-generation to acid-catalyzed bond formation, autonomous self-reinforcing materials will be developed. The broader impacts involve training undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, the development of mechanically adaptable polymers and composites with fundamental implications in self-healing applications. The extended service life of components made from these smart materials will contribute to reducing waste generation.

Plastics and composites are ubiquitous in our lives, being the materials of choice for small applications such as cell-phone screens to large ones such as airplane hulls. These materials have a limited lifetime, which can be reduced under mechanical stresses. This research seeks to improve the lifespan of these materials by developing a self-healing system which harnesses the mechanical stress these materials support to reinforce or heal the material. The specific focus is to find a robust way to produce acid under mechanical stress and use this acid for constructive chemistry. Through development of these new processes, this research will lead to the development of intelligent materials with the ability to self-reinforce or even self-heal when under mechanical fatigue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Professor Moore’s group is developing new methods to produce polymeric materials having the ability to undergo covalent bond remodeling triggered by mechanical force. Specifically, we designed, synthesized, and characterized novel mechanophores and mechanoacids by incorporating functional groups which respond to mechanical force within the polymer backbone. Using the constrained geometries simulate external force (CoGEF) technique, we simulated potential mechanically-active functional groups. These simulations directed our search towards promising candidates that we designed and incorporated into polymers. Our polymers react under mechanical stimulation and generate quantifiable chemical responses. Our method provides a pathway towards designing novel responsive materials from known chemical transformations. These studies expand the chemical diversity of mechanically-active polymer materials while also providing fundamental knowledge on how to rationally design responsive materials for a wide array of applications.

 

Impact & Benefits:

             Not only do our studies provide fundamental details into the nature of mechanochemically-active polymers, but our method describes a rational way to design, predict, and synthesize novel mechanically-active polymers. This knowledge can be applied towards future studies to incorporate these polymers into materials designed for specific stimuli responses. The ability to detect damage in a material upon damage or a specific stimulus allows the development of smart, autonomic self-healing polymers, and composite materials.

 

Background & Explanation:

             The Moore group is interested in creating novel polymeric materials which harness mechanical energy to provide a productive chemical response. Materials systems that have the ability to remodel themselves in response to mechanical damage or degradation are attractive for a wide range of applications, including electronics and autonomous self-healing applications. In order to increase the breadth of applications for these materials, fundamental research is required to expand the repertoire of mechanochemically-active transformations. These studies will allow future researchers to rationally design new mechanophores and mechnoacids with desired structure and functionality. NSF support has allowed postdoctoral researchers, graduate, and undergraduate students to design, synthesize, and characterize novel mechanically-active polymeric materials.

Publications as a Result of this funding:

[1]     Li, J. “Mechanophore Activation at Heterointerface and Surface Crowdedness as a Determining Factor” Ph.D. Thesis, 2016, University of Illinois dissertation supported by [NSF-CHE 130313].

[2]     Nagamani, C. ; Liu, H.; Moore, J.S. "Mechanogeneration of Acid from Oxime Sulfonates", J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2016, 138, 2540-2543. http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/jacs.6b00097. [NSF-CHE 130313].

[3]     Kaitz, J. A. “Synthesis and Applications of Depolymerizable Polyaldehydes” Ph.D. Thesis, 2015, University of Illinois dissertation supported by [NSF-CHE 130313].

[4]     Li, J.; Nagamani, C.; Moore, J. S. "Polymer Mechanochemistry: From Destructive to Productive," Acc. Chem. Res. 2015, 48, 2181-2190. http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.accounts.5b00184 [NSF-CHE 130313].

[5]     Robb, M. J. and Moore, J. S. "A Retro-Staudinger Cycloaddition: Mechanochemical Cycloelimination of a β-Lactam Mechanophore," J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2015, 137, 10946-10949. http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/jacs.5b07345 [NSF-CHE 130313].

[6]     Diesendruck, C. E.; Peterson, G. I.; Kulik, H. J.; Kaitz, J. A.; Mar, B. D.; May, P. A.; White, S. R.; Martinez, T. J.; Boydston, A. J.; Moore, J. S. “Mechanically-Triggered Heterolytic Unzipping of a Low Ceiling Temperature Polymer,” Nat. Chem. 2014, 6, 623-628. http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nchem.1938 [NSF-CHE 130313].

[7]     Shiraki, T.; Diesendruck, C. E. and Moore, J. S. "The Mechanochemical Production of Phenyl Cations through Heterolytic Bond Scissions," Faraday Discuss. 2014, 170, 385-394. http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C4FD00027G [NSF-CHE 130313].

[8]     Diesendruck, C. E.; Zhu, L.; Moore, J. S. “Alkyne Mechanochemistry: Putative Activation by Transoidal Bending,” Chem. Commun. 2014, 50, 13235-13238. http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C4CC03514C [NSF-CHE 130313].
